title: Harmonic Breach: Delve Protocol
tagline: When reality glitches, Heroes debug the world
summary: Modern Earth where video game popularity has reached critical mass, creating 'Imprints' - resonance patterns that eventually manifest as physical 'Delves' where game logic overwrites reality. These pocket dimensions threaten to expand and corrupt baseline reality permanently unless specialized Heroes can enter them and restore harmonic balance. Each Delve reflects the genre and mechanics of whatever games created the original Imprint, leading to bizarre fusion spaces where fantasy dungeons might contain cyberpunk security systems, or horror mansions might have platformer physics.
goals: Penetrate the Delve's layers of corrupted game logic, locate the reality Anchor at its core, and perform the Silencing ritual to collapse the pocket dimension back into normal space-time before it reaches Stage 5 resonance and begins permanently overwriting baseline reality.
victory_conditions: Heroes win collectively by successfully completing enough Challenge thresholds to reduce the Delve's Resonance to zero, representing the successful disruption of the harmful frequency pattern. Individual victory is impossible - either the entire team succeeds in restoring harmonic balance, or they all fail as reality becomes permanently corrupted by the runaway Imprint.

issues.title: Challenge thresholds don't scale with player count
issues.recommendation: Implement dynamic threshold scaling: 2 players = 70% threshold, 3 players = 85% threshold, 4 players = 100% threshold

issues.title: Mind Drive appears significantly more powerful than Body/Agility Drive
issues.recommendation: Rebalance card costs or add more powerful Body/Agility cards to create resource parity

issues.title: Resonance escalation lacks clear mathematical progression
issues.recommendation: Define specific escalation rates: Level 1 = +1 card per round, Level 2 = +2 cards, etc.

issues.title: Avatar generation rates create significant power imbalances
issues.recommendation: Ensure all Avatars generate 6 total Drive per refresh, redistributed across types for specialization

issues.title: Combo cards like Genre Bleed Phenomenon heavily favor higher player counts
issues.recommendation: Add minimum effect floors for player-scaling cards to maintain viability at 2 players

balance.overall_rating: The game has solid cooperative mechanics with meaningful resource constraints, but suffers from scaling issues across player counts and potential Drive type imbalances. The face-down contribution system creates good tension, but fixed challenge thresholds may make the game unwinnable at low player counts or trivial at high player counts.

engagement_hooks: Face-down card contributions create suspense until simultaneous reveal
Cross-genre combinations produce surprising and flavorful results
Escalating difficulty creates mounting pressure and higher stakes
Cooperative coordination without perfect information requires communication and trust
tension_sources: Escalating Delve Deck makes each round more dangerous
Limited Drive tokens force difficult resource allocation decisions

Binary team victory/defeat means individual failures affect everyone
fun.replayability_reason: Perfect combo reveal where multiple cross-genre cards combine for massive threshold success, Narrow failure leading to Resonance spike that changes team strategy, Hero sacrificing powerful Exhaust card to prevent team defeat, Final challenge resolution determining whether reality is saved or corrupted
fun.target_audience: Players have strong control over card play, resource allocation, and tactical coordination. However, the cooperative nature and escalating Delve responses somewhat limit individual impact on outcomes.

As the pocket dimension grows stronger, it actively fights back against the Heroes' presence with increasingly dangerous and unpredictable manifestations.

phases.description: Heroes face the active Challenge by secretly contributing cards that provide the required Tags to meet threshold values. Players must coordinate their limited Drive resources while managing the uncertainty of face-down contributions to overcome the reality distortion.

phases.name: Resolution Phase
phases.description: All contributed cards are revealed simultaneously and Tag values are calculated to determine success or failure. The outcome immediately affects Delve Resonance, Hero resources, and team positioning for future challenges.

Whether to use optional card-sharing abilities vs. keep powerful cards

Coordination about who should hold interrupt cards for next Resonance Phase

turn_structure.phase_flow: Resonance → Challenge → Resolution → Refresh, repeating until Delve is Silenced or reaches critical Resonance
turn_structure.sample_turn: The team enters Round 3 of the 'Abandoned Arcade Horror Delve' with Resonance at Level 2. **Resonance Phase**: The GM reveals 'Possessed Cabinet Cluster' from the Delve Deck - a Challenge requiring 12 [Technology] and 6 [Combat] to overcome. The Scout uses her persistent ability to peek at the next Delve card, revealing even worse challenges ahead. **Challenge Phase**: The team coordinates their approach. The Technomancer plays 'Viral Mythology Spreader' (3 [Technology], 1 [Logic]) for 2 Mind Drive, announcing it will boost other tech cards. The Warrior contributes 'Quantum Norse Hammer' (4 [Combat], 2 [Technology]) for 2 Body + 1 Mind Drive, hoping someone else has Norse/Quantum synergy. The Scout adds 'Cybernetic Reflexes' (3 [Agility], 1 [Technology]) for 1 Body Drive, and the Mystic plays 'Hacked Runes' (2 [Logic], 3 [Technology]) for 1 Mind + 1 Agility Drive. **Resolution Phase**: Cards are revealed simultaneously! The Viral Spreader boosts all other tech cards' secondary Tags by +1, so the team's total becomes: 3+2+1+3=9 [Technology] plus bonuses, and 4 [Combat]. The +1 bonus from Viral Spreader pushes their [Technology] total to 10, but they're still 2 short of the 12 needed and 2 short on [Combat]. The challenge fails! Resonance increases to Level 3, and each Hero must discard one card. **Refresh Phase**: Heroes restore Drive (Technomancer gains 1 Body, 3 Mind, 2 Agility), draw back to hand limit, and prepare for an even more dangerous Round 4 with higher escalation rates. The team realizes they need better coordination and perhaps some Exhaust cards to handle the increasing difficulty.
turn_structure.actions_per_turn: Players contribute cards cooperatively during Challenge Phase, spending Drive tokens to activate card abilities and meet tag thresholds

setup: Each Hero selects an Avatar card and builds a 30-card Action deck from their Avatar's pool. GM selects 1 POI card and 1-2 Theme cards, then builds a Delve deck by combining the POI's required Challenges with Theme-modified cards. Place Resonance marker at Stage 1. Heroes start with Drive tokens equal to their Avatar's generation values and draw opening hands.
agency_justification: Players have complete control over which cards to play, how much Drive to spend, and how to coordinate contributions. Success depends on tactical card selection and team coordination, not random dice rolls.
theme_integration: The card-driven mechanics directly represent how game logic has overridden physical law within the Delve. Players aren't rolling dice because dice don't exist here - they're playing cards because they're literally inside a card game's rule system. The cooperative threshold system represents multiple Heroes working together to generate enough 'counter-resonance' to overcome the Imprint's influence. The Tag system shows how different game genres can bleed together in corrupted reality, allowing seemingly impossible combinations like 'Norse Cyberpunk' or 'Horror Platforming'. Drive tokens represent each Hero's limited capacity to impose their own game logic within the chaotic space, while the escalating Delve Deck shows the Imprint growing stronger and more unstable over time.
core_loop: Each turn: Resonance Phase → Challenge Phase → Resolution Phase → Refresh Phase

specific_rules: All actions require playing cards - no separate dice or stats
Cards must have matching Tags to contribute to Challenge thresholds
Face-down contribution prevents opponents from knowing your exact strategy
Cross-genre cards can combine if they share at least one Tag
Avatar cards provide persistent abilities and Drive generation
mechanism_details.example_interaction: The Challenge requires 8 [Agility] and 4 [Technology]. Player 1 plays a 'Norse Parkour' card (3 Agility) and 'Hacked Runes' card (2 Agility, 3 Technology), spending 2 Mind Drive to activate both. Player 2 adds 'Cybernetic Reflexes' (3 Agility, 1 Technology) for 1 Body Drive.

specific_rules: All Heroes must collectively meet Challenge thresholds to succeed
Players can share certain tagged cards during Refresh Phase
Failure affects entire team - individual success impossible
Team loses together if Delve reaches Stage 5 without Silencing
mechanism_details.example_interaction: The team faces a 15 [Combat] threshold Challenge. No single Hero can contribute more than 6 Combat, so they must coordinate: Warrior contributes 5, Rogue adds 4, Mage provides 3, and Technomancer supplies 3 to barely succeed.

specific_rules: Heroes draw from personal decks built from Avatar pools
Spent cards go to discard, shuffle when deck empty
Some powerful cards have 'Exhaust' - remove from game after use
Drive tokens limit how many cards can be activated per round
Hand size varies by Avatar type (5-9 cards)
mechanism_details.example_interaction: The Mystic has 7 cards in hand but only 4 total Drive tokens. She must choose which 2-3 cards to activate this round, saving her powerful 'Reality Tear' card (costs 3 Drive) for a more critical moment.

specifications.special_features: Color-coded by type, Tag symbols prominent

scoring_formulas.formula: Team victory if Resonance reaches 0 through successful Challenges. Team defeat if Resonance reaches 5.
scoring_formulas.example: Heroes face 8 Challenges requiring 15 total successes to reduce Resonance from 4 to 0. Failing 3+ Challenges pushes Resonance to 5 = defeat.
scoring_formulas.max_potential: Binary: Complete Success or Total Failure

scoring_formulas.formula: Individual contribution tracked by cards played and Drive spent per Challenge
scoring_formulas.example: In Challenge requiring 12 [Combat]: Warrior contributes 8 [Combat] for 3 Body Drive, Scout adds 4 [Combat] for 2 Agility Drive

scoring_formulas.formula: Clue tokens earned for successful investigation Challenges, spent for future advantages
scoring_formulas.example: Team earns 3 Clue tokens from successful [Perception] Challenges. Spend 2 Clues to look at next 3 Delve cards.

mechanism_synergies: Face-down card contributions create tension with Drive limitations - players must commit Drive before seeing if they've contributed enough Tags, leading to nail-biting moments where teams aren't sure if they've met thresholds until the reveal

The three Drive types (Body/Mind/Agility) interact with genre-mixing to create meaningful resource decisions - a Norse Cyberpunk card requiring Body+Mind Drive forces players to balance physical and mental builds while rewarding genre fusion

Avatar abilities and hand management combine to create asymmetric cooperation - the Mystic's ability to preview Delve cards helps the team prepare, while the Scout's Drive conversion helps redistribute resources based on revealed Challenge needs

The escalating Delve Deck and cooperative thresholds create a tension curve where early challenges test teamwork basics while later challenges require near-perfect coordination and optimal card usage to overcome increasingly dangerous reality distortions

Exhaust cards and Drive restoration create a sustainability meta-game where teams must balance short-term power plays against long-term resource management, especially critical in longer Delves where card cycling becomes essential

balance_parameters.drive_generation_per_refresh: 6-8 tokens total per Avatar, distributed across 2-3 types
balance_parameters.average_challenge_threshold: 8-15 total Tags required, scaling with Delve Resonance level
balance_parameters.card_activation_costs: 1-3 Drive per card, with powerful effects costing 2+ and cross-type cards requiring mixed Drive
balance_parameters.hand_size_limits: 5-7 cards depending on Avatar type, with Mystic at 7, Scout at 6, others at 5
balance_parameters.delve_escalation_rate: 1 new Challenge card per Resonance Phase, 2 cards at Resonance 3+, 3 cards at Resonance 4+
balance_parameters.combo_bonus_threshold: 2+ matching genre/tag cards = +1 to primary Tag, 3+ cards = +2 bonus
balance_parameters.resonance_reduction_per_success: 1 point for standard Challenges, 2 points for Boss-type Challenges
balance_parameters.failure_escalation: +1 Resonance per failed Challenge, additional penalties vary by Challenge type
balance_parameters.clue_token_economy: 1 Clue per successful [Perception] Challenge, spend 2 Clues to preview 3 Delve cards or gain 2 Drive of any type

strategic_depth.rationale: Multiple interconnected decision layers: card selection, Drive allocation, timing of powerful abilities, coordination without perfect information, and long-term deck management. The Tag system and combo mechanics add emergent strategic complexity.
highlights: Face-down contribution system requires anticipating teammates' capabilities without revealing your own
Drive economy forces meaningful trade-offs between current challenges and future sustainability
Cross-genre Tag combinations create emergent synergy strategies
Exhaust cards provide high-impact but permanent resource decisions

tension_drama.rationale: Excellent tension generation through escalating Delve pressure, cooperative thresholds with imperfect information, and binary success/failure with team consequences. The Resonance track creates clear mounting stakes.
highlights: Face-down contributions create uncertainty until simultaneous reveal
Escalating Delve Deck makes each round more dangerous than the last
Binary team victory/defeat means every challenge matters
Drive scarcity forces risky decisions about resource commitment

player_agency.rationale: Players have strong control over card play, resource allocation, and tactical coordination. However, the cooperative nature and escalating Delve responses somewhat limit individual impact on outcomes.
